paragraphs.text: No one is exempt from this reality. We are all living with some amount of internal conflict. Shrinking the gap between who we are and who we want to be is completely do-able.
paragraphs.name: f7f5

paragraphs.text: In order to make epic decisions, you want to be in a peak state. Do whatever gets you in a “natural” high where you can hear your highest intuitions. Running, learning, writing in my journal, being in nature, traveling, serving other people, collaborating about big ideas, and being with my family are the conditions when I generally experience a peak-state. Consequently, it is in those conditions that I generally make committed decisions.
paragraphs.name: 9f14

paragraphs.text: Despite being incredibly intelligent, his perfectionism plagues him. He ends up putting-off big projects because the solutions are complex or confusing. He purposefully “distracts” himself with other projects to avoid the unknowns of his big project.
Achieve the life you want. Don’t give-in to lesser goals simply because they have clearer paths.
paragraphs.name: 7cac

paragraphs.text: The best way to do that is to get yourself into a peak or passionate state, and make committed decisions from that state.
paragraphs.name: 63e0

paragraphs.text: Is your current path actually taking you in the direction you truly want to go?If not, how do you get yourself on one that does? Once on a better path, how do you ensure you stay the path to achieve your desired aims?
paragraphs.name: 6aa0

paragraphs.text: However, there is hope for my friend. But it’s going to take a lot of courage. Itstarts with experiencing more stimuli related to the rewards of his goal. This stimuli can be in the form of telling his friends he hates his job and wants something new. It could be in actually looking for other jobs. It could be entertaining thoughts and feelings — negative about his current job and positive about other prospects. Educating himself. Being around people who are successfully doing what he wants to do. All of these things can contribute to him eventually taking the action he truly wants.
paragraphs.name: f71b
ed9d
paragraphs.text: In other words, his over-focus on the risks and under-focus on the reward/goal keeps him from acting. Instead of acting, he purposefully distracts himself away from even thinking about the decision. Thus, he’s getting nowhere closer to solving his problem.

Is your current path actually taking you in the direction you truly want to go?If not, how do you get yourself on one that does? Once on a better path, how do you ensure you stay the path to achieve your desired aims?
paragraphs.name: 6aa0
0c83
paragraphs.text: Act sooner than you’re ready. You’ll never feel ready. Listen to your intuition. It’s speaking to you right now. The more you ignore it, the harder it will be to hear. The more you heed it, the louder and more clear it will be.
Unfortunately, most people don’t make big decisions from a peak state. As a result, their passion fades and they lose momentum.
paragraphs.name: 8e7a

paragraphs.text: These two systems are in constant tension with one another. In every situation, one of these systems is over-ruling the other. Either you are acting, or you’re inhibiting action.
paragraphs.name: bd45

d989ee1eee0c.title: Here’s a simple mindset that will change my life.“If

paragraphs.text: Here’s a simple mindset that will change my life.“If it’s to be — it’s up to me”.Anything that has to happen will happen — if you make it happen.
paragraphs.name: c0ef

paragraphs.text: I’m the only one who CAN do it. No one else. Me.
paragraphs.name: d1ed

virtuals.subtitle: I’m the only one who CAN do it. No one else. Me.

content.subtitle: I’m the only one who CAN do it. No one else. Me.

e7a5dcfb3cf6.title: Holy cow, this was so convicting.

paragraphs.text: Holy cow, this was so convicting. I **hate** uncertainty, and my life is mainly me pursuing difficult but clear-cut paths. This was really good. I also really love the idea of making decisions — and sticking with them — when you feel the best, instead of vice versa. Really good stuff- thanks!

a764b6267e8a.title: We only live this way until we don’t.

paragraphs.text: We only live this way until we don’t. Yes, losing that gap, not just shrinking it, is not only completley doable, it is the reason we are here.
paragraphs.name: f676

paragraphs.text: Great article. ;)
paragraphs.name: 3bb8

paragraphs.text: For me it’s driving. I’m forced to focus on the one task and I often go on autopilot, allowing me to think clearly.
paragraphs.name: 7f35

paragraphs.text: This is very true. The lesser goals with clearer paths always seems to be right until it’s gets too late to act on a bigger goal. Even worse, until someone has done or reached that big goal. Thanks for the insights.
paragraphs.name: f869

ceadba3882b2.title: This does’nt sound like the best advice to me.

paragraphs.text: This does’nt sound like the best advice to me. By making a big decision in a passionate state, I may be acting irrationaly if guided only by what I think is my “passion”, it may fade away and I’d be too commited.
Or maybe this is my inhibition system speaking.
paragraphs.name: 42ac

virtuals.subtitle: Or maybe this is my inhibition system speaking.

content.subtitle: Or maybe this is my inhibition system speaking.

cafb3a1c3203.title: First of all, I guess, is pointing out that alcoholism is a disease.

paragraphs.text: First of all, I guess, is pointing out that alcoholism is a disease. It is a mental disease, physical, and spiritual. Secondly, I find that there is never a real need to paddle upstream. The Universe will take you (me) in the direction we’re supposed to be going. It’s up to us to have faith in the Universe. We always wind up happier.
